title: The if Statement (Your First Fork)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine you're walking down a path and you reach a fork in the road. There's a sign that says: 'If it's raining, take the left path (you have an umbrella there). Otherwise, keep going straight.'

That's EXACTLY what an 'if statement' does in programming! It checks a condition (Is it raining?) and makes a decision:

• If the condition is TRUE → Do this code
• If the condition is FALSE → Skip that code

In C#, we use 'if' to make our programs smart. Instead of always doing the same thing, the program can DECIDE what to do based on the situation.

Think of it like a bouncer at a club: 'If you're 21 or older, you can enter. If not, you can't.' The bouncer checks your age (the condition) and makes a decision!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: The 'if' keyword starts the decision. The condition in parentheses MUST evaluate to true or false (a boolean).
Curly braces contain the code that runs ONLY if the condition is true. If false, everything in the braces is skipped!
This is a comparison that produces true or false. >= means 'greater than or equal to'. If age is 21 or more, it's true!
Code outside the if block ALWAYS runs, whether the condition was true or false. The program continues normally.

challenge.instructions:
Create a simple age verification system:

1. Create an int variable called 'playerAge' and set it to any number
2. Use an if statement to check if playerAge is >= 13
3. If true, display: 'Welcome to the game!'
4. After the if statement, always display: 'Thank you for visiting'

Try changing playerAge to different values and see what happens!
challenge.hint: Remember: if (condition) { code to run if true }. The condition should be playerAge >= 13. Don't forget the curly braces!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting parentheses around the condition: if age >= 13 is WRONG! Must be if (age >= 13)
Forgetting curly braces: While you CAN skip them for one line, it's bad practice. Always use { }!
Using = instead of ==: if (age = 13) ASSIGNS 13 to age! Use == to COMPARE: if (age == 13)
Putting a semicolon after the if: if (age >= 13); is WRONG! No semicolon before the { }
